awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Mechanistic Interplay Between Biofilm Metabolism and Morphogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria can reside as multicellular communities held together by a sticky matrix called biofilms. Cells within these structures, like other multicellular organisms, are challenged by unique conditions but technical limitations have hindered developing chemical and physiological descriptions of biofilm microenvironments and cells. This project will elucidate metabolic and signaling mechanisms in specific regions of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms in response to self-generated oxygen limitations and morphological changes. An interdisciplinary approach employing electrochemical and sample processing techniques will enable direct mapping and measurement of metabolites and gene expression. This project will capitalize on the varied patterns and intense coloration of biofilms to pique the interest of local students and the public in the concepts of multicellularity and metabolism, concepts relevant to medicine and industry, through exhibits and workshops. The PI will expand his laboratory course to include design and maintenance of a free website that hosts analytical software and an interactive database for cataloguing biofilm patterns.

Technical description: Although multicellular life exhibits a seemingly endless array of shapes and patterns, they are morphologically constrained by the metabolic needs of resident cells. Metabolic flexibility can enable energy generation in the chemical gradients that form within such structures; alternatively, cellular communities can change their morphologies to improve access to resources. To address the interplay between metabolism and morphogenesis, this project will explore how self-generated oxygen gradients that form during Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm development alter biofilm morphology.  Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces redox-active phenazines that can support energy generation when oxygen is limiting and in their absence mutants form intricate wrinkled structures that increase biofilm surface area, and lack an anoxic subzone. This research will interrogate a model in which cells in the anoxic zone carry out phenazine-dependent metabolism and sensor-regulator proteins modulate colony wrinkling in response to redox cues. This project will: i) test whether respiratory enzymes catalyze phenazine reduction in the anoxic zone and require specific respiratory enzymes; ii) test whether biofilm cells couple phenazine reduction to carbon source oxidation or fermentation using chromatography/mass spectrometry of colony thin sections; and iii) define the microenvironmental effects of proteins that control wrinkle formation and identify the matrix protein required to build wrinkled colonies.

Intellectual Merit:

Cells commonly grow in groups, stably attached to each other within a self-produced matrix, and outside molecules penetrate poorly into these structures. Cells closer to the outside of a cluster consume resources, such as nutrients for growth and oxygen for cellular respiration, and as a result the cells deeper inside are at risk of starvation/suffocation. Individuals in the various subzones of multicellular structures adjust to their local conditions, using different metabolisms and showing different levels of metabolic activity. This can be observed in cell clusters within larger organisms such as animals and plants but also in structures called biofilms, which are formed by bacteria and other microorganisms.

The metabolic diversity in multicellular structures such as tumors and infectious biofilms is problematic because the metabolic state of a cell affects its suseptibility to the body's defenses and to drugs. In general, the complexity that arises due to metabolic differentiation in biofilms makes it difficult for us to control their behavior, regardless of whether they are being used beneficially (e.g. in food or biofuel production) or whether we are attempting to limit their activities (e.g. in the contamination of pipelines). The Dietrich laboratory studies principles of multicellularity in biofilms formed by the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa. P. aeruginosa is metabolically versatile and can adjust its use of different metabolic pathways depending on environmental conditions. We had previously observed that its metabolic capabilities influence the formation of biofilm structures and in particular that the production of a set of pigments called phenazines, which are damaging to other organisms but beneficial to P. aeruginosa, could play a role in these impacts. The goals of this project have been to characterize metabolisms that contribute to survival in biofilms and the regulatory pathways that link sensing of environmental or intracellular conditions to biofilm matrix production in P. aeruginosa. 

This project has yielded numerous insights into the metabolic strategies used by bacteria in biofilms and the contributions of these strategies to growth, virulence, and antibiotic tolerance. We identified proteins important for the metabolism of phenazines in biofilms and for virulence in a worm host model. We also found that phenazines support metabolism in biofilm subzones where oxygen is scarce and that they contribute to bacterial survival when biofilms are treated with antibiotics. By studying the use of other resources, such as sugars and nitrate (which is also metabolized by P. aeruginosa), we discovered cross-feeding activities in which cells in one subzone produce a substrate used by cells in a different region of the biofilm. This work was enabled by our development of crucial techniques for the preparation of biofilm samples for microscopic analysis and mapping of gene expression and metabolic activity across biofilm depth, which are now being applied to diverse biofilms and which will greatly expand our understanding of the multicellular lifestyle.

Broader Impacts:

A cornerstone of our research program is the colony biofilm model, in which biofilms are grown on a solid gel. Because biofilm pigment production and structural responses to metabolic disruptions are visible by eye (i.e., imaging equipment is not required), colony biofilms are ideal tools for introducing students or non-scientists to microbial diversity. We have leveraged these advantages in educational and outreach activities. We expanded the Project Lab in Microbiology course at Columbia to include a "science communication" component, for which students designed a publicly accessible, web-based catalog describing bacterial isolates they obtained from sampling sites on campus. We also partnered with Columbia's Double Discovery Center, which provides extracurricular learning opportunities for underserved local students, to offer a one-week, high school-level course in bacterial diversity and metabolism called "Microbes of Harlem". Students took samples from sites in the neighborhood and set up enrichments so that they could observe the diversity of pigments and multicellular structures produced by microbes. The course included daily seminars and hands-on practical laboratory experience that would inform students' understanding of the roles of molecular microbiology in health and industry. Dietrich lab members also participated in several other outreach activities and collaborations with the common goal of raising awareness about the biology of biofilms and its relevance for human endeavors, including (1) a "Biohackathon", conducted in conjunction with Columbia's Architecture and Biomedical Engineering programs, at which 60 undergraduate students brainstormed and presented projects or devices at the interfaces between microbiology and these fields and received practical laboratory training; (2) an exhibit at Columbia's Alumni STEM Day, at which families learned about microbiological research conducted on campus and about the diversity of microbes in the human body and in Columbia's neighborhood; and (3) a collaboration with members of the Columbia Space Initiative and NASA to launch an autonomous experiment to study biofilm growth and antibiotic tolerance in microgravity.
